title.narrative: Peace and Development Project (1st Phase APL)

description.narrative: The additional loan for the Peace and Development Project has the same objective as the original project - to assist vulnerable, low-income and displaced populations in rural and urban communities in the conflict affected region of Colombia in order to reduce the risk of their exposure to conflict and mitigate the negative impact of possible derived effects. The loan will both contribute to the consolidation of the strategy advanced by the Project and the expansion of its activities to the Department of Valle del Cauca. Additional benefits will be provided to some 3,604 families in the original departments as well as approximately 300 families from Beneficiary Entities in the Valle de Cauca. The additional loan will merge into one component all the activities under components A (Developing Social, Economic and Environmental Assets in Priority Areas) and B (Support for Displaced Families in the Process of Return and Relocation). The project design also now includes the specific financing for temporary, incremental costs directly related to project management at the local level for project offices, which will be supported under Component C of the operation. In addition, subprojects under Component B will be carried out by Beneficiary Entities.

title.narrative: Component C: POs attain at least 60% of their respective targets for capacity improvement (based on their score in the IPC) betweentime 1 (baseline) and time 2 (end of second year).

baseline.value: 1. Score on IGOP applied in 2006: ASOPATIA: 55%; CONSORNOC: 51%; MAGDALENA MEDIO: 62%; Montes de Maria: 62%; PRODEPAZ: 78%.2.Scores on ICO of Beneficiary Entities in Monitoring System

comment.narrative: IGOP/ICP was applied in 2007 to original 5 POs: FRDPMM: 73%; CONSORNOC: 68%; PRODEPAZ: 63%; CDPMM: 63%; ASOPATIA: 55%.
IGOP will be applied to the new partner organization (Vallenpaz) operating in the Valle del Cauca Region under the AdditionalFinancing Project.

IGOP/ICP has been applied to the new partner organization (Vallenpaz) operating in the Valle del Cauca Region, under theAdditionalFinancing Project. The PO coordinating the Project in the Macizo Colombiano-Alto Patia Region (Asopatia) is no longerinvolved in the Project, but subprojects in this Region are being executed directly by beneficiary organizations under thesupervision of the Administrative Department for Social Prosperity's (former Accion Social) Territorial Directions. IGOP/ICP hasbeen applied in 2011 withthe following performance: VALLENPAZ: 85%; FRDPMM: 59%; CONSORNOC: 67%; PRODEPAZ: 76%; ASOPATIA: 49%;CRIC: 76%. Pending score 2011for CDPMM.

title.narrative: ICO applied to 100% of beneficiary entities implementing subprojects articulated to the strategic territorial plans.

target.value: ICO applied to 100% of beneficiary entities implementing subprojects.

comment.narrative: Results from the ICO final application under the AF phase are expected by end June/12.

actual.value: ICO has been applied to 100% of beneficiary entities. Average rating of initial ICO applied to beneficiary entities under the AFphase are: Norte de Santander: 56; Magdalena Medio: 68; Montes de Maria: 67 and Oriente Antioqueno: 82. National Average: 68

comment.narrative: 32 new subprojects are under implementation under the Additional Financing phase. ICO is being applied to all User/beneficiaryOrganizations implementing subprojects articulated to strategic territorial programs.

title.narrative: PO's financial and procurement audits are satisfactory and 70% of beneficiary entities implementing subprojects comply with the Operational Manual.

target.value: 100% of financial and procurement audits are satisfactory and 70% of beneficiary entities comply with the Operational Manual.

comment.narrative: One PO (out of 6) is no longer involved in the Project due to failure to comply with fiduciary standards required by the NationalAudit Entity (CGR). Subprojects in this Region are being implemented directly by beneficiary organizations under the supervision ofthe Administrative Department of Social Prosperity's (former Accion Social) Territorial Directions. All POs have been complying andare complying with the Project's Operational Manual.

title.narrative: Lower annual incidence of net displacements in the regions served by the Project as the share of nation-wide annual net displacements, adjusted by violence indicators.

baseline.value: Displacement by municipality and violence indicators available for each municipality.

target.value: Lower than in municipalities not targeted by Project. To be measured by impact evaluation using government statistics

comment.narrative: A new review of regional/national displacement rates will be conducted at the end of the Project and will be reflected in theProject's ICR.

Displacement evolution per P&D Region demonstrated that the percentage of internally displaced people dropped considerably between2004 and 2009. The contribution of those regions to the overall displacement of the country represented 17.12% in 2004 and it was11.15% in 2009, a reduction of 38%. It is hard to attribute all of this impact to the P&D project. However, the perception ofrelevant stakeholders is that the P&D is definitely a contributing factor to such change. A new review of regional/nationaldisplacement rates will be conducted at the end of the Project in and will be reflected in the ICR.

title.narrative: Component D: Level of Implementation of Annual Operation Plan in each of the five Project regions.

baseline.value: Total of first subsidiary agreement value at $1.95 million.

actual.value: 5 subsidiary agreements comprising the period 2011-2012 are under implementation and expected to close by July-August 2012.

comment.narrative: Subsidiary Agreements have been signed for calendar year 2010, and for calendar years 2011-2012 period. 2011-2012 operation planis under execution, although with some delay with respect the original plan.

title.narrative: Component A: At least 60 % of target beneficiaries of Component A benefit from social, economic or environmental subprojects financed by the Project.

baseline.value: Number of SISBEN 1 and 2 families by municipality, available in the National Planning Department (DNP) data base of SISBEN

target.value: Food Security: 40,000 families; Income/job opportunities: 10,000 families; Enhancement of access to social services: 9,000families. Total families:59,000

comment.narrative: Targets under the original project (first phase-APL I) have been achieved. The additional financing operation will benefit 3900newfamilies through social, economic and/or environmental subprojects.

Targets under the original project (first phase-APL I) were reached. The additional financing operation is benefiting more than3900 (expected outcome) families through social, economic and/or environmental subprojects. As of the date of this ISR, more than3900families are already benefiting from Project activities.

title.narrative: Component B: At least 80 % of the targets are met in food security, basic sanitation and productive subprojects for returned or relocated families.

baseline.value: Number of returned families by municipality registered in the SIPOD (Iinformation System for Displaced Population)

target.value: Food Security: 8,000 families Access to Social/Economic Opportunities:17,000 families. Habitat and housing improvements: 6000households.

comment.narrative: Targets under the original project (first phase-APL I) were reached. The additional financing operation will benefit 3900 newfamilies through social, economic and/or environmental subprojects.

Targets under the original project (first phase-APL I) were reached. The additional financing operation is already benefiting morethan 3900 families (original expected outcome for the Additional Financing Phase) through social, economic and/or environmentalsubprojects.
